column1: On Early-stage Debunking Rumors on Twitter: Leveraging the Wisdom of Weak Learners;Tu Ngoc Nguyen
column3: Claudia Niederée;Recently a lot of progress has been made in rumor modeling and rumor detection for micro-blogging streams. However
column4: existing automated methods do not perform very well for early rumor detection
column5: which is crucial in many settings
column7: in crisis situations. One reason for this is that aggregated rumor features such as propagation features
column8: which work well on the long run
column9: are - due to their accumulating characteristic - not very helpful in the early phase of a rumor. In this work
column10: we present an approach for early rumor detection
column11: which leverages Convolutional Neural Networks for learning the hidden representations of individual rumor-related tweets to gain insights on the credibility of each tweets. We then aggregate the predictions from the very beginning of a rumor to obtain the overall event credits (so-called wisdom)
column12: and finally combine it with a time series based rumor classification model. Our extensive experiments show a clearly improved classification performance within the critical very first hours of a rumor. For a better understanding
column13: we also conduct an extensive feature evaluation that emphasized on the early stage and shows that the low-level credibility has best predictability at all phases of the rumor lifetime.;https://arxiv.org/abs/1709.04402;

column1: Approximate Integration of streaming data;Michel de Rougemont
column2: Guillaume Vimont;We approximate analytic queries on streaming data with a weighted reservoir sampling. For a stream of tuples of a Datawarehouse we show how to approximate some OLAP queries. For a stream of graph edges from a Social Network
column3: we approximate the communities as the large connected components of the edges in the reservoir. We show that for a model of random graphs which follow a power law degree distribution
column4: the community detection algorithm is a good approximation. Given two streams of graph edges from two Sources
column5: we define the {\em Community Correlation} as the fraction of the nodes in communities in both streams. Although we do not store the edges of the streams
column6: we can approximate the Community Correlation and define the {\em Integration of two streams}. We illustrate this approach with Twitter streams

column1: Mitigating Overexposure in Viral Marketing;Rediet Abebe
column3: Jon Kleinberg;In traditional models for word-of-mouth recommendations and viral marketing
column4: the objective function has generally been based on reaching as many people as possible. However
column5: a number of studies have shown that the indiscriminate spread of a product by word-of-mouth can result in overexposure
column6: reaching people who evaluate it negatively. This can lead to an effect in which the over-promotion of a product can produce negative reputational effects
column7: by reaching a part of the audience that is not receptive to it.;;

column1: How should one make use of social influence when there is a risk of overexposure?; we show how it captures a number of the qualitative phenomena associated with overexposure
column2: and for the main formulation of our model
column3: we provide a polynomial-time algorithm to find the optimal marketing strategy. We also present simulations of the model on real network topologies
column4: quantifying the extent to which our optimal strategies outperform natural baselines;https://arxiv.org/abs/1709.04123;;

column1: Local Community Detection in Dynamic Networks;Daniel J. DiTursi
column3: Petko Bogdanov;"Given a time-evolving network
column4: how can we detect communities over periods of high internal and low external interactions? To address this question we generalize traditional local community detection in graphs to the setting of dynamic networks. Adopting existing static-network approaches in an ""aggregated"" graph of all temporal interactions is not appropriate for the problem as dynamic communities may be short-lived and thus lost when mixing interactions over long periods. Hence
column5: dynamic community mining requires the detection of both the community nodes and an optimal time interval in which they are actively interacting.";;

column1: Network Clocks: Detecting the Temporal Scale of Information Diffusion;Daniel J. DiTursi
column3: Petko Bogdanov;Information diffusion models typically assume a discrete timeline in which an information token spreads in the network. Since users in real-world networks vary significantly in their intensity and periods of activity
column4: our objective in this work is to answer: How to determine a temporal scale that best agrees with the observed information propagation within a network? A key limitation of existing approaches is that they aggregate the timeline into fixed-size windows
column5: which may not fit all network nodes' activity periods. We propose the notion of a heterogeneous network clock: a mapping of events to discrete timestamps that best explains their occurrence according to a given cascade propagation model. We focus on the widely-adopted independent cascade (IC) model and formalize the optimal clock as the one that maximizes the likelihood of all observed cascades. The single optimal clock (OC) problem can be solved exactly in polynomial time. However
column6: we prove that learning multiple optimal clocks(kOC)
column7: corresponding to temporal patterns of groups of network nodes
column8: is NP-hard. We propose scalable solutions that run in almost linear time in the total number of cascade activations and discuss approximation guarantees for each variant. Our algorithms and their detected clocks enable improved cascade size classification (up to 8 percent F1 lift) and improved missing cascade data inference (0.15 better recall). We also demonstrate that the network clocks exhibit consistency within the type of content diffusing in the network and are robust with respect to the propagation probability parameters of the IC model.;https://arxiv.org/abs/1709.04015;

column1: Proceedings of the 25th International Symposium on Graph Drawing and Network Visualization (GD 2017);Fabrizio Frati
column2: Kwan-Liu Ma;This is the arXiv index for the electronic proceedings of the 25th International Symposium on Graph Drawing and Network Visualization (GD 2017)
column3: which was held in Boston
column4: U.S.A.
column5: September 25-27 2017. It contains the peer-reviewed and revised accepted papers with an optional appendix.;https://arxiv.org/abs/1709.04228;

column1: Forbidden triads and Creative Success in Jazz: The Miles Davis Factor;Balazs Vedres;This article argues for the importance of forbidden triads - open triads with high-weight edges - in predicting success in creative fields. Forbidden triads had been treated as a residual category beyond closed and open triads
column2: yet I argue that these structures provide opportunities to combine socially evolved styles in new ways. Using data on the entire history of recorded jazz from 1896 to 2010
column3: I show that observed collaborations have tolerated the openness of high weight triads more than expected
column4: observed jazz sessions had more forbidden triads than expected
column5: and the density of forbidden triads contributed to the success of recording sessions
column6: measured by the number of record releases of session material. The article also shows that the sessions of Miles Davis had received an especially high boost from forbidden triads.;https://arxiv.org/abs/1709.03787;

column1: Establishing Personal Trust-based Connections in Distributed Teams;Fabio Calefato
column2: Filippo Lanubile;Trust is a factor that dramatically contributes to the success or failure of distributed software teams. We present a research model showing that social communication between distant developers enables the affective appraisal of trustworthiness even from a distance
column3: thus increasing project performance. To overcome the limitations of self-reported data
column4: typically questionnaires
column5: we focus on software projects following a pull request-based development model and approximate the overall performance of a software project with the history of successful collaborations occurring between developers.;https://arxiv.org/abs/1709.03777;

column1: Principled Multilayer Network Embedding;Weiyi Liu
column3: Pin-Yu Chen
column4: Toyotaro Suzumura
column5: Lingli Chen;"Multilayer network analysis has become a vital tool for understanding different relationships and their interactions in a complex system
column6: where each layer in a multilayer network depicts the topological structure of a group of nodes corresponding to a particular relationship. The interactions among different layers imply how the interplay of different relations on the topology of each layer. For a single-layer network
column7: network embedding methods have been proposed to project the nodes in a network into a continuous vector space with a relatively small number of dimensions
column8: where the space embeds the social representations among nodes. These algorithms have been proved to have a better performance on a variety of regular graph analysis tasks
column10: or multi-label classification. In this paper
column11: by extending a standard graph mining into multilayer network
column12: we have proposed three methods (""network aggregation
column13: ""results aggregation"" and ""layer co-analysis"") to project a multilayer network into a continuous vector space. From the evaluation
column14: we have proved that comparing with regular link prediction methods
column15: ""layer co-analysis"" achieved the best performance on most of the datasets
column16: while ""network aggregation"" and ""results aggregation"" also have better performance than regular link prediction methods.";https://arxiv.org/abs/1709.03551;

column1: Learning Graph Topological Features via GAN;Weiyi Liu
column3: Min Hwan Oh
column4: Sailung Yeung
column5: Pin-yu Chen
column7: Lingli Chen;Inspired by the generation power of generative adversarial networks (GANs) in image domains
column8: we introduce a novel hierarchical architecture for learning characteristic topological features from a single arbitrary input graph via GANs. The hierarchical architecture consisting of multiple GANs preserves both local and global topological features and automatically partitions the input graph into representative stages for feature learning. The stages facilitate reconstruction and can be used as indicators of the importance of the associated topological structures. Experiments show that our method produces subgraphs retaining a wide range of topological features
column9: even in early reconstruction stages (unlike a single GAN
column10: which cannot easily identify such features
column11: let alone reconstruct the original graph). This paper is firstline research on combining the use of GANs and graph topological analysis.;https://arxiv.org/abs/1709.03545;

column1: Reconstruction of multiplex networks with correlated layers;Valerio Gemmetto
column2: Diego Garlaschelli;The characterization of various properties of real-world systems requires the knowledge of the underlying network of connections among the system's components. Unfortunately
column3: in many situations the complete topology of this network is empirically inaccessible
column4: and one has to resort to probabilistic techniques to infer it from limited information. While network reconstruction methods have reached some degree of maturity in the case of single-layer networks (where nodes can be connected only by one type of links)
column5: the problem is practically unexplored in the case of multiplex networks
column7: each with a different type of links
column8: coexist. Even the most advanced network reconstruction techniques
column9: if applied to each layer separately
column10: fail in replicating the observed inter-layer dependencies making up the whole coupled multiplex. Here we develop a methodology to reconstruct a class of correlated multiplexes which includes the World Trade Multiplex as a specific example we study in detail. Our method starts from any reconstruction model that successfully reproduces some desired marginal properties
column11: including node strengths and/or node degrees
column12: of each layer separately. It then introduces the minimal dependency structure required to replicate an additional set of higher-order properties that quantify the portion of each node's degree and each node's strength that is shared and/or reciprocated across pairs of layers. These properties are found to provide empirically robust measures of inter-layer coupling. Our method allows joint multi-layer connection probabilities to be reliably reconstructed from marginal ones
column13: effectively bridging the gap between single-layer properties and truly multiplex information.;https://arxiv.org/abs/1709.03918;

column1: Distributed Estimation Recovery under Sensor Failure;Mohammadreza Doostmohammadian
column3: Houman Zarrabi
column4: Usman A. Khan;Single time-scale distributed estimation of dynamic systems via a network of sensors/estimators is addressed in this letter. In single time-scale distributed estimation
column5: the two fusion steps
column10: a large number of consensus iterations at every step of the system dynamics. We particularly discuss the problem of failure in the sensor/estimator network and how to recover for distributed estimation by adding new sensor measurements from equivalent states. We separately discuss the recovery for two types of sensors
column11: namely \alpha and \beta sensors. We propose polynomial order algorithms to find equivalent state nodes in graph representation of system to recover for distributed observability. The polynomial order solution is particularly significant for large-scale systems.;https://arxiv.org/abs/1709.03855;

column1: Observational Equivalence in System Estimation: Contractions in Complex Networks;Mohammadreza Doostmohammadian
column3: Houman Zarrabi
column4: Usman Khan;Observability of complex systems/networks is the focus of this paper
column5: which is shown to be closely related to the concept of contraction. Indeed
column6: for observable network tracking it is necessary/sufficient to have one node in each contraction measured. Therefore
column7: nodes in a contraction are equivalent to recover for loss of observability
column8: implying that contraction size is a key factor for observability recovery. Here
column9: using a polynomial order contraction detection algorithm
column10: we analyze the distribution of contractions
column11: studying its relation with key network properties. Our results show that contraction size is related to network clustering coefficient and degree heterogeneity. Particularly
column12: in networks with power-law degree distribution
column13: if the clustering coefficient is high there are less contractions with smaller size on average. The implication is that estimation/tracking of such systems requires less number of measurements
column14: while their observational recovery is more restrictive in case of sensor failure. Further
column15: in Small-World networks higher degree heterogeneity implies that there are more contractions with smaller size on average. Therefore
column16: the estimation of representing system requires more measurements
column17: and also the recovery of measurement failure is more limited. These results imply that one can tune the properties of synthetic networks to alleviate their estimation/observability recovery.;https://arxiv.org/abs/1709.03846;

column1: Coin-flipping
column3: and grass-hopping for generating random graphs from matrices of edge probabilities;Arjun S. Ramani
column4: Nicole Eikmeier
column5: David F. Gleich;Common models for random graphs
column6: such as Erd\H{o}s-R\'{e}nyi and Kronecker graphs
column7: correspond to generating random adjacency matrices where each entry is non-zero based on a large matrix of probabilities. Generating an instance of a random graph based on these models is easy
column9: by flipping biased coins (i.e. sampling binomial random variables) for each possible edge. This process is inefficient because most large graph models correspond to sparse graphs where the vast majority of coin flips will result in no edges. We describe some not-entirely-well-known
column11: techniques that will enable us to sample a graph by finding only the coin flips that will produce edges. Our analogies for these procedures are ball-dropping
column13: but may need extra work due to duplicate edges
column15: which results in no duplicated work or extra edges.;;

column1: Social Media Text Processing and Semantic Analysis for Smart Cities;João Filipe Figueiredo Pereira;With the rise of Social Media
column2: people obtain and share information almost instantly on a 24/7 basis. Many research areas have tried to gain valuable insights from these large volumes of freely available user generated content.;;

column1: A Multilayer and Time-varying Structural Analysis of the Brazilian Air Transportation Network;Bernardo Costa
column3: Klaus Wehmuth
column4: Artur Ziviani;This paper provides a multilayer and time-varying structural analysis of one air transportation network
column5: having the Brazilian air transportation network as a case study. Using a single mathematical object called MultiAspect Graph (MAG) for this analysis
column6: the multilayer perspective enables the unveiling of the particular strategies of each airline to both establish and adapt in a moment of crisis its specific flight network. Similarly
column7: the time-varying perspective allows multi-scale analysis considering different time periods
column8: and thus assessing the impact of the economic crisis on how the different airlines establish their routes as well as the flights that use these routes. Altogether
column9: besides the multilayer and time-varying structural analysis of the Brazilian air transportation network
column10: this paper also acts as a proof-of-concept for the MAG potential for the modeling and analysis of high-order networks.;https://arxiv.org/abs/1709.03360;

column1: Local Edge Betweenness based Label Propagation for Community Detection in Complex Networks;Hamid Shahrivari
column3: identification and detection community structures in complex networks is an important factor in extracting useful information from networks. Label propagation algorithm with near linear-time complexity is one of the most popular methods for detecting community structures
column4: yet its uncertainty and randomness is a defective factor. Merging LPA with other community detection metrics would improve its accuracy and reduce instability of LPA. Considering this point
column5: in this paper we tried to use edge betweenness centrality to improve LPA performance. On the other hand
column6: calculating edge betweenness centrality is expensive
column8: we try to use local edge betweenness and present LPA-LEB (Label Propagation Algorithm Local Edge Betweenness). Experimental results on both real-world and benchmark networks show that LPA-LEB possesses higher accuracy and stability than LPA when detecting community structures in networks.;https://arxiv.org/abs/1709.03135;

column1: Robustness of Interdependent Random Geometric Networks;Jianan Zhang
column3: Eytan Modiano;We propose an interdependent random geometric graph (RGG) model for interdependent networks. Based on this model
column4: we study the robustness of two interdependent spatially embedded networks where interdependence exists between geographically nearby nodes in the two networks. We study the emergence of the giant mutual component in two interdependent RGGs as node densities increase
column5: and define the percolation threshold as a pair of node densities above which the giant mutual component first appears. In contrast to the case for a single RGG
column6: where the percolation threshold is a unique scalar for a given connection distance
column8: multiple pairs of percolation thresholds may exist
column9: given that a smaller node density in one RGG may increase the minimum node density in the other RGG in order for a giant mutual component to exist. We derive analytical upper bounds on the percolation thresholds of two interdependent RGGs by discretization

column1: Tabloids in the Era of Social Media? Understanding the Production and Consumption of Clickbaits in Twitter;Abhijnan Chakraborty
column3: Ayushi Mrigen
column4: Niloy Ganguly;With the growing shift towards news consumption primarily through social media sites like Twitter
column5: most of the traditional as well as new-age media houses are promoting their news stories by tweeting about them. The competition for user attention in such mediums has led many media houses to use catchy sensational form of tweets to attract more users - a process known as clickbaiting. In this work
column6: using an extensive dataset collected from Twitter
column7: we analyze the social sharing patterns of clickbait and non-clickbait tweets to determine the organic reach of such tweets. We also attempt to study the sections of Twitter users who actively engage themselves in following clickbait and non-clickbait tweets. Comparing the advent of clickbaits with the rise of tabloidization of news
column8: we bring out several important insights regarding the news consumers as well as the media organizations promoting news stories on Twitter.;https://arxiv.org/abs/1709.02957;

column1: Advanced Page Rank Algorithm with Semantics
column3: Out Links and Google Analytics;Aritra Banerjee
column4: Shrey Choudhary;In this paper we have modified the existing page ranking mechanism as an advanced Page Rank Algorithm based on Semantics Inlinks Outlinks and Google Analytics. We have used Semantics page ranking to rank pages according to the word searched and match it with the metadata of the website and provide a value of rank according to the highest priority.We have also used Google analytics to store the number of hits of a website in a particular variable and add the required percentage amount to the ranking procedure.The proposed algorithm is used to find more relevant information according to users query.So this concept is very useful to display most valuable pages on the top of the result list on the basis of user browsing behaviour which reduce the search space to a large scale.;https://arxiv.org/abs/1709.02858;

column1: Rates of Convergence of Spectral Methods for Graphon Estimation;Jiaming Xu;This paper studies the problem of estimating the grahpon model - the underlying generating mechanism of a network. Graphon estimation arises in many applications such as predicting missing links in networks and learning user preferences in recommender systems. The graphon model deals with a random graph of;;
Cognitive networks: brains
column3: and civilizations;Dmitrii Yu. Manin
column4: Yuri I. Manin;"In this short essay
column5: we discuss some basic features of cognitive activity at several different space-time scales: from neural networks in the brain to civilizations. One motivation for such comparative study is its heuristic value. Attempts to better understand the functioning of ""wetware"" involved in cognitive activities of central nervous system by comparing it with a computing device have a long tradition. We suggest that comparison with Internet might be more adequate. We briefly touch upon such subjects as encoding
column7: and Saussurean trichotomy langue/langage/parole in various environments.";https://arxiv.org/abs/1709.03114;

column1: Connectivity in Interdependent Networks;Jianan Zhang
column2: Eytan Modiano;We propose and analyze a graph model to study the connectivity of interdependent networks. Two interdependent networks of arbitrary topologies are modeled as two graphs
column3: where every node in one graph is supported by supply nodes in the other graph
column4: and a node fails if all of its supply nodes fail. Such interdependence arises in cyber-physical systems and layered network architectures.;;

column1: Fractional Dynamics of Network Growth Constrained by aging Node Interactions;Hadiseh Safdari
column3: Amirhossein Shirazi
column4: Moein Khalighi
column5: Gholamreza Jafari
column6: Marcel Ausloos;"In many social complex systems
column7: in which agents are linked by non-linear interactions
column8: the history of events strongly influences the whole network dynamics. However
column9: a class of ""commonly accepted beliefs"" seems rarely studied. In this paper
column10: we examine how the growth process of a (social) network is influenced by past circumstances. In order to tackle this cause
column11: we simply modify the well known preferential attachment mechanism by imposing a time dependent kernel function in the network evolution equation. This approach leads to a fractional order Barabasi-Albert (BA) differential equation
column12: generalizing the BA model. Our results show that
column14: an aging process is observed for the network dynamics. The aging process leads to a decay for the node degree values
column15: thereby creating an opposing process to the preferential attachment mechanism. On one hand
column16: based on the preferential attachment mechanism
column17: nodes with a high degree are more likely to absorb links"; but
column19: a node's age has a reduced chance for new connections. This competitive scenario allows an increased chance for younger members to become a hub. Simulations of such a network growth with aging constraint confirm the results found from solving the fractional BA equation. We also report
column21: an investigation of the collaboration network between Hollywood movie actors. It is undubiously shown that a decay in the dynamics of their collaboration rate is found
column22: - even including a sex difference. Such findings suggest a widely universal application of the so generalized BA model.;https://arxiv.org/abs/1709.02960

column1: Glassy states of aging social networks;F. Hassanibesheli
column3: H. Safdari
column4: M. Ausloos
column5: G. R. Jafari;"Individuals often develop reluctance to change their social relations
column7: even though their interactions with their environment evolve with time. Some memory effect is loosely present deforcing changes. In other words
column9: relations do not change easily. In order to investigate some history or memory effect on social networks
column10: we introduce a temporal kernel function into the Heider conventional balance theory
column11: allowing for the ""quality"" of past relations to contribute to the evolution of the system. This memory effect is shown to lead to the emergence of aged networks
column12: thereby perfectly describing and the more so measuring the aging process of links (""social relations""). It is shown that such a memory does not change the dynamical attractors of the system
column13: but does prolong the time necessary to reach the ""balanced states"". The general trend goes toward obtaining either global (""paradise"" or ""bipolar"") or local (""jammed"") balanced states
column14: but is profoundly affected by aged relations. The resistance of elder links against changes decelerates the evolution of the system and traps it into so named glassy states. In contrast to balance";https://arxiv.org/abs/1709.02951;
